results.headline: Review: ‘Mojave’ Looks at the Corrosive Effects of Hollywood
results.summary_short: The film, written and directed by William Monahan, finds a celebrity in the desert, then under siege.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mojave

results.headline: Review: ‘Prescription Thugs,’ a Confessional Documentary on Substance Abuse
results.summary_short: Chris Bell, using his own family as a window onto the subject, examines why Americans take far too many prescription drugs.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Prescription Thugs

results.headline: Review: ‘Monster Hunt’ Features a Baby Beast on the Run With Its Surrogate Parents
results.summary_short: Raman Hui’s live-action and computerized hybrid, a runaway hit in China, conjures a cute newborn creature pursued by other beasts and by human bounty hunters.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Monster Hunt

results.headline: Review: In ‘Ip Man 3,’ Donnie Yen Brawls With Mike Tyson and Others
results.summary_short: Fists fly as usual in this installment of the ‘Ip Man’ series, which pits Mr. Yen’s character against a brutal gang while his wife is threatened by illness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ip Man 3

results.headline: Review: ‘Martyrs,’ a Slashing Remake, Centers on Two Friends
results.summary_short: This film features women caught up in revenge, torture and the supernatural.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Martyrs

results.headline: Review: Arturo Ripstein’s ‘Bleak Street,’ the Story of a Mexican Murder Case
results.summary_short: This film is a fictionalized chronicle of the deaths of Alberto and Alejandro Pérez Jiménez, small wrestlers who were killed in a botched robbery in 2009.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bleak Street

results.headline: Review: In ‘Intruders,’ a Surprise Awaits Home Invaders
results.summary_short: Three would-be burglars who break into a home find themselves in an unexpected game of cat and mouse with its agoraphobic owner.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Intruders

results.headline: Review: ‘Band of Robbers’ Riffs on Mark Twain Characters in Today’s Missouri
results.summary_short: This comedy, written and directed by Aaron and Adam Nee, offers variations on “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn” and “The Adventures of Tom Sawyer.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Band of Robbers

results.headline: Review: In ‘Norm of the North,’ a Polar Bear Takes a Stand
results.summary_short: In this animated film, the voluble title character heads to New York to fight a proposal for condo construction in his habitat.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Norm of the North

results.headline: Review: ‘In the Shadow of Women’ Focuses on the Female Sides of a Triangle
results.summary_short: This drama from Philippe Garrel depicts two filmmakers, one of whom is a philandering husband. But Mr. Garrel is more interested in the story’s women.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Shadow of Women

results.headline: Review: ‘Ride Along 2’ Reloads Twin Barrels of Ice Cube and Kevin Hart
results.summary_short: The stars reunite as mismatched police partners, now on a Miami drug lord’s trail. Ken Jeong, Olivia Munn and Sherri Shepherd lend a hand.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ride Along 2

results.headline: Review: Richard Gere, ‘The Benefactor’ Who Pulls the Strings
results.summary_short: In ‘The Benefactor,’ Mr. Gere, who is dependent on morphine, makes others dependent on him.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Benefactor

results.headline: Review: ‘Moonwalkers,’ a Conspiracy-Theory Comedy
results.summary_short: This film, starring Ron Perlman and Rupert Grint, invests too much in the comedy potential of things that haven’t been funny for a long while.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moonwalkers

results.display_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi
results.headline: Review: In Michael Bay’s ‘13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi,’ Clarity Isn’t the Objective
results.summary_short: Mr. Bay has moderately scaled back his extreme-cinema approach for the story about the attack on the American diplomatic mission in 2012.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi

results.headline: Review: ‘A Perfect Day’ About Aid Workers in the Balkans
results.summary_short: Benicio Del Toro and Tim Robbins star in this Fernando León de Aranoa’s film set in the Balkan countryside in 1995.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Perfect Day

results.display_title: Troublemakers: The Story of Land Art
results.headline: Review: ‘Troublemakers: The Story of Land Art,’ a Documentary
results.summary_short: James Crump’s film looks at artists who, in the early 1960s, headed into the open spaces of North America to mold the land.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Troublemakers: The Story of Land Art

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Treasure,’ Digging for Something of Value in Romania
results.summary_short: Corneliu Porumboiu, this film’s director, waits for dramatic events to arise instead of forcing the action.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Treasure

results.headline: Review: ‘Anesthesia’ Ponders the Meaningfulness of Life
results.summary_short: This film considers the cruel paradox of living amid life-enhancing technological miracles that don’t fulfill a yearning for a more purposeful existence.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Anesthesia

results.headline: Review: In ‘Unlucky Plaza,’ a Comic Hostage Crisis via Tabloid Storytelling
results.summary_short: Ken Kwek’s debut feature, set in Singapore, centers on a hapless diner owner, loan shark, motivational speaker and other motley characters.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unlucky Plaza

results.headline: Review: Visiting a Lolita-Land of Sorts With ‘Lamb’
results.summary_short: “Lamb,” with Ross Partridge as its director, star and screenwriter, based his film on a novel by Bonnie Nadzam.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lamb
